# 2022 FIVB Men's Volleyball Nations League

The 2022 FIVB Men's Volleyball Nations League was the third edition of the FIVB Volleyball Nations League, a annual international volleyball tournament organized by the Fédération Internationale de Volleyball (FIVB). The tournament took place from June 7 to June 19, 2022, in Rimini, Italy, with a total of 16 teams participating.

## Qualification

The qualification process for the 2022 FIVB Men's Volleyball Nations League began with the FIVB Volleyball World Rankings. The top 16 teams in the world rankings qualified directly for the tournament. The teams were divided into four pools of four teams each, with the top two teams from each pool advancing to the final round.

## Format

### Preliminary round

The preliminary round consisted of 12 matches played in two weeks, with each team playing two matches per week. The teams were divided into four pools of four teams each, with the following pairings:

* Pool 1: Brazil, China, Poland, and Russia
* Pool 2: Argentina, Canada, France, and Italy
* Pool 3: Iran, Japan, Netherlands, and Serbia
* Pool 4: Bulgaria, Germany, Slovenia, and United States

### Final round

The final round consisted of a knockout stage, with the top two teams from each pool advancing to the quarterfinals. The quarterfinals were played in a best-of-three format, with the winners advancing to the semifinals. The semifinals and finals were played in a best-of-three format, with the winner receiving the gold medal.

## Rule changes

For the 2022 FIVB Men's Volleyball Nations League, the FIVB introduced several rule changes. The most notable change was the introduction of the "video challenge" system, which allowed teams to challenge certain refereeing decisions during the match. The challenge system was implemented to improve the accuracy of refereeing decisions and to reduce controversy.

article:
Norfolk and Western 611

The Norfolk and Western 611 is a historic steam locomotive built in 1950 by the Norfolk and Western Railway (N&W) for passenger service. The locomotive is a Class J 4-8-4 Northern, a type of articulated steam locomotive designed for high-speed passenger service.

# Design and abilities

The Norfolk and Western 611 was designed by L. R. de Forest, the chief mechanical engineer of the N&W at the time, and built by the Roanoke Shops in Roanoke, Virginia. The locomotive features a 4-8-4 wheel arrangement, with two leading wheels, eight driving wheels, and four trailing wheels. This configuration allowed for improved traction and stability, making it well-suited for high-speed passenger service.

The 611 has a 75-inch driving wheel diameter, a boiler pressure of 300 pounds per square inch (psi), and a grate area of 74.5 square feet. Its firebox is equipped with an atomizing stoker, which helped to improve combustion efficiency and reduce smoke emissions. The locomotive's cab is located at the rear of the engine, with a crew of five: engineer, fireman, two brakemen, and a head brakeman.

The 611 was capable of reaching speeds of up to 100 miles per hour (160 km/h), making it one of the fastest steam locomotives in the United States at the time of its introduction. Its top speed was achieved on a test run in 1950, during which the locomotive reached 100 miles per hour on the N&W's Washington District.

# History

## Revenue service

The Norfolk and Western 611 entered revenue service on August 26, 1950, on the N&W's Washington District, carrying passengers between Roanoke, Virginia, and Washington, D.C. The locomotive was initially assigned to the N&W's prestige passenger train, the Powhatan Arrow, which ran between Washington, D.C., and Cincinnati, Ohio.

During its revenue service, the 611 hauled many notable passengers, including President Harry S. Truman and Governor of Virginia, John S. Battle. The locomotive's regular crew consisted of experienced engineers and firemen, who were known for their skill and attention to detail.

## First retirement

The Norfolk and Western 611 was retired from revenue service on September 25, 1959, after nearly nine years of operation. The locomotive was replaced by diesel-electric locomotives, which were deemed more efficient and cost-effective. The 611 was placed in storage at the N&W's Roanoke Shops, where it remained for several years.

## First mainline excursion service

In 1961, the Norfolk and Western 611 was restored to operating condition and began to haul excursion trains on the N&W's main line. The locomotive's first excursion run was on June 17, 1961, when it hauled a train of cars between Roanoke, Virginia, and Lynchburg, Virginia.

The 611's excursion service was a huge success, with thousands of passengers traveling behind the historic locomotive. The excursion runs were typically 50-100 miles in length and featured a variety of cars, including observation cars, dining cars, and coaches.

## Second retirement

The Norfolk and Western 611 was retired from excursion service in 1975, due to a combination of factors, including the increasing cost of operating a steam locomotive and the availability of more modern diesel-electric locomotives. The locomotive was placed in storage at the N&W's Roanoke Shops, where it remained for several years.

## Second mainline excursion service

In 1981, the Norfolk and Western 611 was restored to operating condition and began to haul excursion trains on the N&W's main line once again. This time, the locomotive was operated by the Norfolk Southern Railway (NS), which had acquired the N&W in 1982.

The 611's second excursion service was marked by a number of notable runs, including a trip to the 1983 NS Transportation Museum in Chattanooga, Tennessee, and a series of runs along the N&W's former Chesapeake and Ohio Railway (C&O) line between Cincinnati, Ohio, and Huntington, West Virginia.

## Post-NS excursion service

In 1994, the Norfolk and Western 611 was retired from excursion service for the final time, due to a combination of factors, including the increasing cost of operating a steam locomotive and the availability of more modern diesel-electric locomotives.

Today, the Norfolk and Western 611 is on display at the NS Transportation Museum in Chattanooga, Tennessee, where it is maintained in operating condition and occasionally runs on special occasions. The locomotive is a testament to the ingenuity and craftsmanship of the engineers and craftsmen who built it, and a reminder of the importance of preserving our rail heritage.

# Accidents and incidents

During its revenue service, the Norfolk and Western 611 was involved in a number of minor accidents and incidents, including a collision with a freight train in 1954 and a derailment in 1957. However, the locomotive suffered no major damage in either incident and was able to continue operating without interruption.

# In popular culture

The Norfolk and Western 611 has been featured in a number of films and television shows, including the 1950s television series "The Lone Ranger" and the 1960s television series "Route 66." The locomotive has also been the subject of several books and documentaries, including a 1960s book titled "The Norfolk and Western 611" and a 2000s documentary titled "The Steam Locomotive: A History."

* The 611's excursion service was a huge success, with thousands of passengers traveling behind the historic locomotive.
* The locomotive's restoration and operation have been supported by a number of organizations, including the Norfolk Southern Railway and the National Railroad Museum.

article:
Glyn Johns

Glyn Johns is a British record producer, musician, and engineer who has worked with numerous renowned bands and artists in the music industry. Born on February 15, 1942, in London, England, Johns began his career in music at a young age, eventually becoming one of the most respected and sought-after producers in the business.

#Early life

Glyn Johns was born to a musical family and was exposed to music from an early age. His father, Roy Johns, was a saxophonist who played with several dance bands in the 1930s and 1940s. Johns' mother, Enid, was a singer and a pianist who taught music at a local school. The Johns family would often have music sessions at home, with Glyn and his siblings learning to play instruments and sing along.

#Career in music and recording

##Early years: 1959–1963

###IBC Studios and as performing artist

In 1959, Johns began working at IBC Studios in London, where he was exposed to the latest recording techniques and technologies. During this time, he also started performing as a musician, playing drums and guitar with several local bands. In 1961, Johns joined the British band The Yardbirds, playing drums on several of their early singles.

###The Rolling Stones 1962–1963

In 1962, Johns joined The Rolling Stones as their guitarist and backing vocalist. During his tenure with the band, he appeared on several of their early recordings, including "I Wanna Be Your Man" and "Not Fade Away." Johns left the band in 1963, citing creative differences and a desire to focus on his work as a producer.

###As engineer for Shel Talmy

In 1963, Johns began working as an engineer for Shel Talmy, a renowned producer and songwriter. Talmy had produced several hits for The Kinks, and Johns assisted him on several of these sessions. During this time, Johns also honed his skills as a producer and developed his own distinct approach to recording.

##Peak years: 1964–1984

###The Kinks, the Who, and Eric Clapton and as independent

In 1964, Johns began working with The Kinks, producing several of their albums, including "The Kinks Are the Village Green Preservation Society" and "Something Else by The Kinks." He also worked with The Who on their 1967 album "A Quick One," and with Eric Clapton on his 1967 album "Rainbow Bridge."

###The Rolling Stones 1965–1975

In 1965, Johns rejoined The Rolling Stones as their producer, working on several of their albums, including "Beggars Banquet," "Let It Bleed," and "Sticky Fingers." During this time, Johns developed a reputation as a producer who could coax the best out of his artists, while also pushing them to experiment and try new things.

###The Small Faces, the Faces, Humble Pie, and Ronnie Lane and Pete Townshend

In the late 1960s, Johns began working with several other bands, including The Small Faces, The Faces, and Humble Pie. He also worked with solo artists such as Ronnie Lane and Pete Townshend, producing several of their albums and singles.

###Led Zeppelin

In 1969, Johns produced Led Zeppelin's debut album, which would go on to become one of the most influential and successful albums in rock history.

###The Beatles

In 1969, Johns worked with The Beatles on several of their final recordings, including the "Get Back" sessions and the album "Let It Be."

###Procol Harum, Joe Cocker, the Move, and the Easybeats and others

In the early 1970s, Johns worked with several other bands and artists, including Procol Harum, Joe Cocker, The Move, and The Easybeats. He also produced several albums and singles for these acts.

###The Steve Miller Band, Bob Dylan, the Band, the Eagles

In the mid-1970s, Johns worked with several other bands and artists, including The Steve Miller Band, Bob Dylan, The Band, and The Eagles.

###Other American acts

In the late 1970s, Johns worked with several other American acts, including The Doobie Brothers, The Doobie Brothers' spinoff band, Michael McDonald, and Kenny Loggins.

###Joan Armatrading

In the 1980s, Johns worked with the British singer-songwriter Joan Armatrading, producing several of her albums and singles.

###The Clash

In 1982, Johns produced The Clash's album "Combat Rock," which would go on to become one of the band's most successful releases.

##1985–present

In the 1980s and 1990s, Johns continued to work in the music industry, producing several albums and singles for various artists. In the 2000s, he began to focus more on his work as a musician, releasing several albums and touring with various bands.

#Approach to recording

Glyn Johns is known for his distinctive approach to recording, which emphasizes a more natural and organic sound. He is a strong believer in the importance of capturing a live performance, and often uses a more minimalist approach to recording, relying on the skills of his musicians to deliver a great performance.

#Family

Glyn Johns is married to Annie Johns, and they have two children together. His son, Ethan Johns, is a musician and producer who has worked with several notable artists, including Ryan Adams and Michael Kiwanuka.

#Legacy

Glyn Johns is widely regarded as one of the most influential and respected producers in the music industry. His work with The Rolling Stones, The Kinks, and Led Zeppelin has had a lasting impact on rock music, and his approach to recording has influenced generations of producers and musicians.

article:
**Typhoon Doksuri**

Typhoon Doksuri, known in the Philippines as Typhoon Maring, was a powerful and destructive tropical cyclone that affected several countries in East Asia in September 2017. The storm caused widespread damage and loss of life, particularly in the Philippines and Vietnam.

**#Meteorological history**

Typhoon Doksuri originated from a tropical disturbance that formed over the western Pacific Ocean on September 10, 2017. The system slowly intensified as it moved westward, eventually developing into a tropical depression on September 12. The depression strengthened into a tropical storm on September 13, and was subsequently named Doksuri by the Japan Meteorological Agency (JMA).

Doksuri continued to intensify as it moved westward, eventually reaching typhoon strength on September 15. The storm reached its peak intensity on September 16, with maximum sustained winds of 195 km/h (120 mph) and a minimum central pressure of 920 hPa. Doksuri then began to weaken as it interacted with the Asian landmass, eventually dissipating on September 20.

**#Preparations**

###Philippines

The Philippine government issued a signal number 2 in several provinces in the northern Philippines, including Cagayan and Isabela, on September 15. The National Disaster Risk Reduction and Management Council (NDRRMC) also issued a warning for possible landslides and flooding in the affected areas.

The Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration (PAGASA) also issued a public storm warning signal number 1 in several areas in the northern Philippines, including Metro Manila.

###Taiwan

The Taiwanese government issued a land warning for southeastern Taiwan on September 16, as Doksuri was expected to bring strong winds and heavy rain to the area.

###China

The Chinese government issued a yellow alert for strong winds and heavy rain in several provinces, including Fujian and Guangdong, on September 16.

**#Impact**

###Philippines

Widespread flooding occurred in several provinces in the northern Philippines, including Cagayan and Isabela, due to heavy rainfall associated with Doksuri. The flooding caused significant damage to crops and infrastructure.

The MB Aya Express, a passenger ferry, sank off the coast of Cagayan on September 16, resulting in the deaths of at least 10 people. The ferry was traveling from the town of Lal-lo to the city of Tuguegarao when it encountered strong winds and heavy rain associated with Doksuri.

###Taiwan

Doksuri brought strong winds and heavy rain to southeastern Taiwan on September 16, causing widespread power outages and flooding in several areas. At least two people were killed and several others injured in the storm.

###China

Fujian

Doksuri brought strong winds and heavy rain to Fujian province on September 16, causing widespread power outages and flooding in several areas. At least five people were killed and several others injured in the storm.

Beijing, Jilin and Hebei

Doksuri brought strong winds and heavy rain to the Beijing-Tianjin-Hebei region on September 17, causing widespread power outages and flooding in several areas. At least two people were killed and several others injured in the storm.

###Vietnam

Doksuri made landfall in central Vietnam on September 17, bringing strong winds and heavy rain to several areas. At least 13 people were killed and several others injured in the storm. The storm also caused widespread damage to crops and infrastructure.

**#Aftermath**

###China

The Chinese government estimated that the national losses due to Doksuri were around 10 billion yuan (1.4 billion USD). The storm also caused significant damage to crops and infrastructure in several provinces, including Fujian and Guangdong.

**#Retirement**

Doksuri was retired from the naming list for the western Pacific Ocean by the RSMC Tokyo - Typhoon Center in 2018.

2022 Serbian general election

The 2022 Serbian general election was held on April 3, 2022, to elect members of the National Assembly of Serbia, the country's unicameral parliament, as well as the President of Serbia.

### Inter-party dialogues on electoral conditions

In the lead-up to the election, various inter-party dialogues were held on the conditions for the elections. Several parties, including the Serbian Progressive Party (SNS) and the Socialist Party of Serbia (SPS), advocated for changes to the electoral system to ensure a more proportional representation of parties in the parliament.

### Constitutional referendum

In 2020, a constitutional referendum was held in Serbia, which introduced several changes to the country's constitution, including the introduction of direct presidential elections. The new electoral law, which was also introduced as a result of the referendum, allowed for the election of the President of Serbia through a two-round system, with a runoff election to be held if no candidate secured a majority of the vote in the first round.

### Environmental protests

In the months leading up to the election, protests were held in several cities across Serbia, primarily focused on environmental issues. article:
Dobbs v. Jackson Women's Health Organization

The Dobbs v. Jackson Women's Health Organization case, decided on June 24, 2022, was a landmark United States Supreme Court decision that overruled the constitutional right to abortion established by the court in the 1973 Roe v. Wade decision and the 1992 Planned Parenthood v. Casey decision. The ruling effectively allowed states to regulate or prohibit abortion, and it has had significant impacts on the healthcare landscape, politics, and society in the United States.

# Background

## Common Law

Prior to the 1973 Roe v. Wade decision, the legality of abortion varied from state to state, with some allowing it under certain circumstances and others prohibiting it altogether. The common law stance on abortion was largely influenced by the English legal tradition, which considered abortion to be a crime and subject to prosecution.

## Constitutional Right

In Roe v. Wade, the Supreme Court held that the right to abortion was a constitutional right derived from the Due Process Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment. The court established a trimester framework for regulating abortion, with varying levels of state oversight and regulation at different stages of pregnancy. This framework was modified in the 1992 Planned Parenthood v. Casey decision, which introduced the "undue burden" standard for evaluating abortion regulations.

## Evolution of the Composition of the Supreme Court

The composition of the Supreme Court has undergone significant changes since the Roe v. Wade decision. In the 2020 presidential election, President Donald Trump appointed three conservative justices, including Amy Coney Barrett, Neil Gorsuch, and Brett Kavanaugh, which shifted the court's ideological balance. The addition of these justices created a 6-3 conservative majority, which was seen as a significant threat to abortion rights.

# Gestational Age Act

## Lower Courts

The case of Dobbs v. Jackson Women's Health Organization originated in the state of Mississippi, where the state legislature had enacted the Gestational Age Act in 2018. The act prohibited abortion after 15 weeks of gestation, with exceptions for medical emergencies or cases where the fetus was determined to be viable. The Jackson Women's Health Organization, a local abortion clinic, challenged the act in federal court, arguing that it was unconstitutional.

The lower courts, including the Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals, ruled in favor of the state of Mississippi, upholding the constitutionality of the Gestational Age Act. The Supreme Court agreed to hear the case, which was argued in December 2021.

# Supreme Court

## Oral Argument

The oral argument in Dobbs v. Jackson Women's Health Organization was notable for its confrontational and tense tone. The justices engaged in a spirited debate, with the conservative justices questioning the constitutionality of the abortion right and the liberal justices defending it. The argument centered on the question of whether the federal Constitution protects a woman's right to terminate her pregnancy, and whether the states have the authority to regulate or prohibit abortion.

## Leaked Draft Opinion

In May 2022, a leaked draft opinion written by Justice Samuel Alito was published by Politico, revealing that the court was poised to overturn Roe v. Wade. The leaked opinion, which was later confirmed by the court, stated that the Constitution does not confer a right to abortion and that the authority to regulate abortion should be returned to the states.

### Reactions

The leak of the draft opinion sparked widespread outrage and protests across the United States. Women's rights groups, reproductive health organizations, and advocates for social justice condemned the decision as a threat to women's autonomy and equality. The leak also sparked a heated debate about the court's legitimacy and the role of the judiciary in American society.

### Investigation

The Supreme Court launched an investigation into the leak, with Chief Justice John Roberts ordering an investigation by the Marshal of the Court. The investigation was led by a team of outside investigators, who reviewed security footage and interviewed court employees.

# Opinions

## Majority Opinion

The majority opinion in Dobbs v. Jackson Women's Health Organization was written by Justice Samuel Alito and joined by all five conservative justices. The opinion held that the Constitution does not confer a right to abortion and that the authority to regulate abortion should be returned to the states. The opinion also struck down the trimester framework established in Roe v. Wade and the undue burden standard established in Planned Parenthood v. Casey.

## Concurrences

Justice Clarence Thomas wrote a concurrence in which he argued that the court's decision should not be limited to the case of abortion. He argued that the court should reconsider its decision in other cases that have established constitutional rights, including the right to same-sex marriage and the right to same-sex intimacy.

## Concurrence in Judgment

Justice Neil Gorsuch wrote a concurrence in judgment, in which he agreed with the majority that the Constitution does not confer a right to abortion. However, he argued that the majority's opinion should not be read to suggest that the states have unfettered authority to regulate abortion.

## Dissent

The dissenting opinion in Dobbs v. Jackson Women's Health Organization was written by Justice Sonia Sotomayor and joined by Justices Stephen Breyer and Elena Kagan. The dissent argued that the majority's decision was a grave injustice that would have far-reaching consequences for women's health and equality.

# Impact

## Pre-decision

Prior to the decision in Dobbs v. Jackson Women's Health Organization, abortion was a highly contentious issue in the United States. The Supreme Court's decision in Roe v. Wade had established a constitutional right to abortion, but the court's decision in Planned Parenthood v. Casey had created a regulatory framework that allowed states to impose certain restrictions on abortion.

## Post-decision

The decision in Dobbs v. Jackson Women's Health Organization has had significant impacts on the healthcare landscape, politics, and society in the United States. The decision has allowed states to regulate or prohibit abortion, leading to a wave of new laws and regulations that restrict access to abortion.

### State Laws Restricting Abortion

Since the decision in Dobbs v. Jackson Women's Health Organization, numerous states have enacted laws restricting abortion. These laws include bans on abortion after a certain gestational age, restrictions on abortion procedures, and requirements for abortion clinics to meet certain standards.

#### EMTALA and Federal Preemption

The decision in Dobbs v. Jackson Women's Health Organization has also raised questions about the application of the Emergency Medical Treatment and Active Labor Act (EMTALA) to abortion. EMTALA requires hospitals to provide emergency treatment, including abortion, in certain circumstances. The decision in Dobbs v. Jackson Women's Health Organization has led to concerns that states may be able to preempt federal law and restrict access to abortion.

### State Laws Expanding Abortion Access

While many states have restricted access to abortion, others have expanded access to abortion. These laws include repeals of restrictive abortion laws, expansion of Medicaid coverage for abortion, and creation of safe havens for women seeking abortion.

### Congressional Proposals

The decision in Dobbs v. Jackson Women's Health Organization has also led to a series of congressional proposals aimed at codifying the right to abortion. These proposals include the Women's Health Protection Act, which would prohibit states from restricting access to abortion, and the EACH Act, which would require Medicaid coverage for abortion.

### Executive Action by President Biden

President Biden has taken executive action to protect access to abortion. In 2022, he issued an executive order aimed at protecting access to abortion and reproductive healthcare. The order prohibits states from restricting access to abortion and requires health insurers to cover abortion services.

### Medical Abortion, In Vitro Fertilization, and Other Processes

The decision in Dobbs v. Jackson Women's Health Organization has also raised questions about the application of abortion laws to other medical procedures. Medical abortion, in vitro fertilization, and other processes have been the subject of controversy and debate.

### Data Privacy

The decision in Dobbs v. Jackson Women's Health Organization has also raised concerns about data privacy. The decision has led to concerns that states may be able to collect sensitive information about women seeking abortion, including their personal medical history and other sensitive information.

### 2022 and 2024 United States Election Seasons

The decision in Dobbs v. Jackson Women's Health Organization has become a major issue in the 2022 and 2024 United States election seasons. Candidates for office have been asked to take positions on the issue, and voters have expressed strong opinions about the decision.

### Effects on Abortion Rates

The decision in Dobbs v. Jackson Women's Health Organization has had significant effects on abortion rates in the United States. According to data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), abortion rates in the United States have declined since the decision.

### Effects on Infant Mortality

The decision in Dobbs v. Jackson Women's Health Organization has also had significant effects on infant mortality rates in the United States. According to data from the CDC, infant mortality rates in the United States have increased since the decision.

# Reaction

## Legal Journalists

## Political

### Support

### Opposition

Civil rights groups have been vocal in their reaction to the decision in Dobbs v. Jackson Women's Health Organization. Many have argued that the decision is a threat to women's rights and a step backward for civil rights.

## Health and Education

Health and education experts have been vocal in their reaction to the decision in Dobbs v. Jackson Women's Health Organization. Many have argued that the decision will have significant negative impacts on women's health and education.

## International

International leaders have been vocal in their reaction to the decision in Dobbs v. Jackson Women's Health Organization. Many have expressed concern about the impact on women's health and equality, while others have celebrated the decision as a victory for conservative values.

## News Organizations

News organizations have been vocal in their reaction to the decision in Dobbs v. Jackson Women's Health Organization. Many have provided in-depth coverage of the decision and its impact.

## Public

The public has been vocal in their reaction to the decision in Dobbs v. Jackson Women's Health Organization. Many have expressed strong opinions about the decision, with some celebrating it as a victory for conservative values and others expressing outrage and disappointment.

## Corporate and Celebrity

Corporate and celebrity leaders have been vocal in their reaction to the decision in Dobbs v. Jackson Women's Health Organization. Many have expressed concern about the impact on women's health and equality, while others have celebrated the decision as a victory for conservative values.

# Legacy

## Cultural and Political Effects

The decision in Dobbs v. Jackson Women's Health Organization has had significant cultural and political effects. The decision has become a major issue in the 2022 and 2024 United States election seasons, and it has sparked a national conversation about women's rights and reproductive healthcare.

## Medical and Sociological Effects

**Canada Convoy Protest**

The Canada convoy protest was a series of protests and blockades that took place across Canada in February 2022, sparked by a dispute over COVID-19 vaccine mandates and passports. The protests, which began as a convoy of truckers traveling to Ottawa, eventually grew into a nationwide movement, resulting in disruptions to Canadian life and significant economic losses.

**Background**

The Canada convoy protest was the culmination of several months of growing frustration among Canadians regarding the federal government's COVID-19 policies, particularly the mandatory vaccination requirements for truckers and other essential workers. The protests were organized by a coalition of groups, including the Canadian Trucking Alliance and the United We Roll movement, which had been advocating for the repeal of the vaccine mandates and passports.

### Protest Goals

The primary goals of the convoy protest were to:

1. Demand the repeal of the federal government's COVID-19 vaccine mandates and passports for truckers and other essential workers.

article:
The Whale (2022 film)

The Whale is a 2022 American drama film directed by Darren Aronofsky, based on the 2012 play of the same name by Samuel D. Hunter. The film stars Brendan Fraser, Sadie Sink, Hong Chau, and Samantha Morton.

# Plot

The Whale is a drama film that tells the story of Charlie, a reclusive English teacher who weighs over 600 pounds and is struggling to come to terms with his own mortality. Charlie is a complex and troubled individual who has been living in isolation, and the story explores his inner struggles as he grapples with his own demons.

As the story unfolds, it becomes clear that Charlie's life is a tragic one, marked by loss and heartache. He is a former seminary student who was forced to leave after his father's death, and he has since been struggling to find his place in the world. Despite his physical limitations, Charlie is a deeply emotional and sensitive person who is desperate for human connection.

The film takes a dramatic turn when Charlie's estranged mother, Liz, returns to care for him after a heart attack. Liz is a complicated figure who has a history of abuse and neglect, and her return sets off a chain of events that forces Charlie to confront his past and his own mortality.

Throughout the film, Charlie's story is intertwined with that of his nurse, Liz, and his student, Ellie. Liz is a kind and compassionate person who becomes a source of comfort and support for Charlie, while Ellie is a rebellious and free-spirited individual who challenges Charlie's views on life and death.

As the story reaches its climax, Charlie is faced with a series of difficult choices that will determine the course of his life. Will he continue to struggle with his weight and his inner demons, or will he find a way to escape his tragic circumstances and start anew?

# Cast

The Whale features a talented ensemble cast, including:

* Brendan Fraser as Charlie
* Sadie Sink as Ellie
* Hong Chau as Liz
* Samantha Morton as Mary
* Ty Simpkins as Thomas
* Sam Douglas as Mr. Lickman
* Jeff Pope as Father
* Gustavo Díaz as Hector

# Production

## Writing and Casting

The Whale is based on the 2012 play of the same name by Samuel D. Hunter, which premiered at the Humana Festival of New American Plays. The play was a critical success, and it was later adapted into a film by Darren Aronofsky.

The screenplay was written by Samuel D. Hunter, and it was adapted for the screen by Darren Aronofsky and Ari Handel. The film was produced by Darren Aronofsky, Ari Handel, and Scott Franklin, and it was executive produced by Samuel D. Hunter.

The casting process for The Whale was a long and difficult one, with Brendan Fraser being the first choice for the role of Charlie. Fraser had previously worked with Aronofsky on the film The Revenant, and he was eager to collaborate with the director again.

## Filming

The Whale was filmed on location in Winnipeg, Manitoba, Canada, and it was shot over a period of 25 days. The film was shot in a mix of digital and 35mm formats, and it was edited by Jay Rabinowitz.

The production design for The Whale was created by Ethan Tobman, and it was a key element in bringing the film's themes and ideas to life. The set design was a combination of real and constructed elements, and it included a large living room, a kitchen, and a bedroom.

The cinematography for The Whale was handled by Matthew Libatique, who worked closely with Aronofsky to create a visual style that was both intimate and epic. The film's color palette was muted and subdued, with a focus on blues and greys.

# Release

article:
Martin Amis is a British novelist, essayist, and screenwriter, known for his provocative and lyrically written works that often explore the human condition, politics, and culture.

# Early life

Martin Amis was born on August 25, 1949, in Oxford, England, to British novelist Kingsley Amis and his first wife, Hilary Ann Bardwell. His father's influence would later shape Amis's writing style and subject matter. Amis's early life was marked by a strict upbringing, with a strong emphasis on education and a love of literature.

# Early writing

Amis began writing at an early age, producing short stories and poetry while still a teenager. His first published work, a short story called "The Last Days of a Hero," appeared in the New Statesman in 1969. This early writing was met with critical acclaim, and Amis soon gained recognition as a talented young writer.

# Main career

## 1980s and 1990s

Amis's first novel, "The Rachel Papers," was published in 1973, but it was his 1984 novel "Money" that brought him widespread critical acclaim and commercial success. This novel, a satirical exploration of Thatcherite Britain, cemented Amis's reputation as a major literary talent. The 1980s and 1990s saw the publication of several more novels, including "London Fields" (1989) and "Time's Arrow" (1991), both of which further solidified Amis's position as a leading writer.

## 2000s

The 2000s saw Amis continue to push the boundaries of literary fiction. His 2000 novel "The Information" explored the intersection of technology and humanity, while 2003's "House of Meetings" delved into the complexities of human relationships and identity. Amis's writing during this period was characterized by its lyricism, complexity, and often provocative subject matter.

## 2010s and 2020s

In the 2010s, Amis continued to write novels that explored a wide range of themes and subjects. His 2014 novel "The Zone of Interest" examined the complexities of human relationships and the nature of evil, while 2018's "Inside Story" offered a satirical exploration of modern society. Amis's writing in the 2020s has continued to be marked by its lyricism and complexity, with a focus on exploring the human condition and the world around us.

## Other work

### University of Manchester

In 2013, Amis was appointed as a professor of creative writing at the University of Manchester, a position he held until 2016. During his time at the university, Amis taught creative writing and offered guidance to students, drawing on his own experiences as a writer.

# Personal life

## Death

Martin Amis passed away on August 19, 2023, at the age of 73. His death was met with widespread tributes from the literary community, with many praising his innovative and provocative writing style.

# Views

## Writing

Amis has long been known for his provocative and often controversial views on writing and literature. He has argued that the role of the writer is to challenge and subvert conventional thinking, and that the best writing is often that which is most difficult to understand.

## Nuclear proliferation

Amis has been a vocal critic of nuclear proliferation, arguing that the threat of nuclear war is one of the greatest dangers facing humanity. His 1986 novel "The Rachel Papers" explores the theme of nuclear war, and Amis has continued to write about the subject throughout his career.

## Geopolitics

Amis has been critical of Western intervention in the Middle East, arguing that it has often been motivated by self-interest rather than a genuine desire to promote democracy and stability. His 2014 novel "The Zone of Interest" explores the complexities of human relationships and the nature of evil in the context of World War II and its aftermath.

## Electoral politics

Amis has been critical of the electoral politics of modern society, arguing that the emphasis on spin and image over substance has led to a decline in intellectual and moral discourse. His 2000 novel "The Information" explores the intersection of technology and humanity, and Amis has continued to write about the impact of technology on society.

## Islam and Islamism

Amis has written extensively about Islam and Islamism, arguing that the religion is often misunderstood and misrepresented in the Western media. His 1989 novel "London Fields" explores the theme of identity and belonging in the context of a multicultural society.

## Euthanasia

Amis has been a vocal supporter of euthanasia, arguing that it is a fundamental human right to be able to die with dignity. His 2014 novel "The Zone of Interest" explores the complexities of human relationships and the nature of evil, and Amis has continued to write about the subject throughout his career.

## Agnosticism

Amis has described himself as an agnostic, arguing that the existence of God is a mystery that cannot be proven or disproven. His writing often explores the human condition and the search for meaning in a seemingly meaningless world.

article:
Elemental (2023 film)

Elemental is a 2023 American computer-animated romantic fantasy film produced by Pixar Animation Studios and directed by Peter Sohn. The film is set in a world where elements are alive and takes place in Element City, a metropolis where humans and elemental beings coexist.

**Plot**

The film follows the story of Ember, a young and fiery elemental who lives in Element City. Ember is a passionate and adventurous individual who dreams of exploring the world beyond her city. She befriends Wade, a water elemental who is quiet and reserved. Despite their differences, the two form a strong bond and begin to navigate the complexities of their relationship.

As Ember and Wade's relationship deepens, they face challenges from their respective elemental communities. Ember's fire elementals are wary of her friendship with Wade, while Wade's water elementals are concerned about his association with Ember. The two must find a way to reconcile their differences and be together, all while learning to control their elemental powers and understand the true nature of their world.

**Voice cast**

* Leah Clark as Ember
* Mamoudou Athie as Wade
* Ronnie del Carmen as Balthazar
* Wendi McLendon-Covey as Dispatcher
* Jason Schwartzman as Brent
* Lisa Delaney as Linda
* Suki Waterhouse as Calla
* Sherry Lynn as Mrs. Giggles

**Production**

#### Development

Elemental was first announced in June 2019, with Peter Sohn set to direct and write the film. The project marked Sohn's second film as a director, following The Good Dinosaur. Sohn has stated that he was inspired by his own experiences as a child, growing up in a Korean-American household and feeling like an outsider. He wanted to create a story that explored themes of identity, community, and acceptance.

#### Writing

Sohn wrote the screenplay for Elemental, drawing inspiration from his own life experiences and observations of the world around him. He wanted to create a story that was both personal and universal, and one that would resonate with audiences of all ages. The film's script underwent several revisions, with Sohn working closely with his team to refine the story and characters.

#### Casting

article:
**2022 United States infant formula shortage**

The 2022 United States infant formula shortage was a critical shortage of infant formula in the United States, caused by a combination of factors including supply chain issues, recall and plant shutdown, import restrictions, and market concentration.

**Causes**

The infant formula shortage was caused by a complex interplay of factors, including:

### Supply chain issues

Supply chain disruptions have been a major challenge in the production and distribution of infant formula. The COVID-19 pandemic led to widespread supply chain disruptions, resulting in shortages of essential ingredients and materials. Additionally, the shortage of truck drivers and warehouse workers contributed to the delays in shipping and receiving infant formula.

### Recall and plant shutdown

In February 2022, the infant formula manufacturer Abbott Nutrition recalled several of its products due to contamination concerns. The company's Sturgis, Michigan plant was shut down as a result, further exacerbating the shortage.

#### Alleged problems at Sturgis plant

The Sturgis plant has been the subject of controversy and allegations of poor quality control and safety practices. In September 2021, the plant was cited by the FDA for 13 serious violations, including inadequate sanitation and contamination control. The plant was also accused of producing infant formula with high levels of bacteria, including Cronobacter sakazakii, which can cause life-threatening infections in infants.

### Import restrictions

The United States has strict regulations on the importation of infant formula, which has limited the ability of companies to import formula from other countries. The FDA requires that imported formula meet strict safety and labeling standards, which can be time-consuming and costly to meet.

### Market concentration

The infant formula market is dominated by a few large manufacturers, including Abbott Nutrition, Enfamil, and Gerber. This concentration of market share has led to concerns about the fragility of the supply chain and the potential for disruptions to affect a large proportion of the market.

**Effects**

The infant formula shortage has had significant effects on families, healthcare providers, and the broader community:

## Sale and donation of breast milk

The shortage has led to an increased demand for breast milk donations. Breastfeeding support groups and milk banks have seen an uptick in requests for donations, with some organizations reporting a 50% increase in demand.

## Use of alternative foods

Families have been forced to turn to alternative foods, including cow's milk and oat-based formulas, to feed their infants. However, these alternatives may not provide the same nutritional benefits as traditional infant formula.

## Hospitalizations

The shortage has led to an increase in hospitalizations related to infant formula. According to reports, some hospitals have seen a 20% increase in admissions due to formula-related issues, including dehydration and malnutrition.

## Bot usage

The shortage has led to an increase in bot usage, with online platforms experiencing a surge in demand for infant formula. Some companies have reported a 500% increase in online sales, with many customers turning to social media and online forums to seek out alternative sources of formula.

## Shortage in Canada

The infant formula shortage has also affected Canada, with some provinces experiencing widespread shortages. The Canadian government has taken steps to address the shortage, including importing formula from other countries and increasing production at domestic manufacturers.

**Responses**

In response to the shortage, the government, manufacturers, and other stakeholders have taken various steps to address the issue:

## Efforts to prevent price gouging

The Federal Trade Commission (FTC) has taken action to prevent price gouging, with some companies being accused of increasing prices by as much as 500%. The FTC has also launched an investigation into price gouging practices.

## Efforts to increase supply

Manufacturers have increased production to meet demand, with some companies reportedly working around the clock to produce formula. Additionally, the FDA has approved the importation of formula from other countries to help alleviate the shortage.

## Efforts to restore production

Abbott Nutrition has announced plans to restore production at its Sturgis plant, with the company working to address the issues that led to the recall and plant shutdown.

## Investigations

Several investigations have been launched to examine the causes of the shortage and ensure that it does not happen again:

### Congressional investigation

The House Committee on Oversight and Reform has launched an investigation into the shortage, with a focus on the role of supply chain disruptions and market concentration.

### FDA investigation

The FDA has launched an investigation into the safety and quality control practices at the Sturgis plant, as well as the broader infant formula industry.

### ABC News investigation

ABC News has launched an investigation into the shortage, with a focus on the impact on families and the role of manufacturers in exacerbating the shortage.

### DOJ investigation

The Department of Justice (DOJ) has launched an investigation into price gouging practices, with a focus on companies that have increased prices during the shortage.

**Commentary**

The infant formula shortage has sparked a debate about the role of breastfeeding vs. formula feeding, as well as the federal response to the crisis:

## Breast milk vs. formula debate

**Background**

### Format

The tournament was a knockout competition, with 128 players competing in a single-elimination format. **Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles (1987 TV series)**

The Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles (TMNT) is an American animated television series produced by Fred Wolf Entertainment in association with Mirage Studios. The series is based on the comic book characters of the same name created by Kevin Eastman and Peter Laird. The show premiered on December 10, 1987, and ran for 10 seasons, with a total of 193 episodes.

**Series overview**

The series follows the adventures of four anthropomorphic turtles, named after the Italian artists of the Renaissance: Leonardo, Michelangelo, Donatello, and Raphael. The Turtles are trained in the art of ninjutsu by a wise rat named Splinter, who is also their father figure. The Turtles live in the sewers of New York City, where they battle against the evil forces of the villainous Shredder and his Foot Clan.

### Seasons 1–7

The first seven seasons of the show follow the Turtles as they face various challenges and villains, including the Shredder, Krang, and the Kraang. The Turtles also meet new allies, such as Casey Jones, April O'Neil, and the power-hungry baboon, Hamato Yoshi. The show's storyline is largely episodic, with each episode featuring a self-contained story and a new villain.

#### Vacation in Europe

In the third season, the Turtles embark on a vacation to Europe, where they encounter various European villains, including the villainous Rat King. The episode is notable for its lighthearted and humorous tone, which deviates from the show's usual dark and serious tone.

### Seasons 8–10

The show features several recurring villains, including:

#### Other characters

The show features several other characters, including:

The 1987 TMNT series was developed by Fred Wolf Entertainment in association with Mirage Studios. The show was written by a team of writers, including Fred Wolf, Mark Edens, and Leo Ordonez.

### Voice acting

The show features a talented cast of voice actors, including:

**Soundtrack**

The TMNT series features a memorable and catchy soundtrack, which includes the theme song, "Turtle Power." The show's score was composed by Billy West, who also voiced the character of Hamato Yoshi.

The TMNT series was syndicated in the United States and around the world, airing on various networks and television stations. The show was also released on DVD and video on demand.

**2023 FIBA Basketball World Cup**

The 2023 FIBA Basketball World Cup was the 19th edition of the FIBA Basketball World Cup, a quadrennial international basketball tournament for men's national teams. The tournament took place from August 25 to September 10, 2023, in the Philippines, Japan, and Indonesia.

**Host selection**

The host selection process began in 2019, with the International Basketball Federation (FIBA) announcing that the Philippines, Japan, and Indonesia had submitted bids to host the tournament. A voting process was held among FIBA member countries, with the three countries emerging as the top contenders.

**Voting results**

The voting results were as follows:

* Philippines: 39 votes
* Japan: 24 votes
* Indonesia: 16 votes

The Philippines was ultimately awarded the hosting rights, with Japan and Indonesia also being awarded hosting rights for various groups and matches.

**Teams**

A total of 32 teams participated in the tournament, with 24 teams qualifying through the FIBA Basketball World Cup Qualifiers and 8 teams receiving direct invitations.

The seeding for the draw was based on the FIBA World Rankings as of February 2, 2023.

**Squads**

Each team was required to submit a squad of 12 players, with a maximum of 3 naturalized players per team.

**Venues**

The tournament was played across 9 venues, with 7 indoor arenas and 2 training venues and hotels.

The 2023 FIBA Basketball World Cup Organizing Committee was responsible for overseeing the preparations for the tournament.

article:
Cocaine Bear

Cocaine Bear is a 2023 American dark comedy thriller film written and directed by Phil Lord and Christopher Miller. The film is based on a true story about a bear that ingested a large quantity of cocaine and became aggressive, leading to a series of events that ultimately resulted in the death of the bear.

# Plot

The film follows the story of a black bear that ingests a large quantity of cocaine that had been left behind by a group of smugglers in the woods. The bear becomes aggressive and begins to wreak havoc on the surrounding area, leading to a series of events that ultimately result in its death.

As the story unfolds, a group of people become entangled in the bear's destructive path, including a park ranger, a detective, and a group of tourists. The film takes a darkly comedic tone as it explores the consequences of the bear's actions and the reactions of those around it.

# Cast

The film features a talented ensemble cast, including:

* Keanu Reeves as a park ranger who becomes embroiled in the bear's destructive path
* John Hawkes as a detective who is tasked with solving the mystery of the bear's death
* Oakes Fegley as a young boy who befriends the bear
* J.K. Simmons as a gruff but lovable park ranger
* W. Earl Brown as a suspect in the bear's death
* Margo Martindale as a park ranger's wife who becomes embroiled in the investigation

# Inspiration

The film is inspired by a true story that took place in 1985 in Georgia, where a black bear was found dead with a large quantity of cocaine in its stomach. The bear had ingested the cocaine after raiding a stash of the substance that had been left behind by a group of smugglers.

## Creative liberties

The film takes creative liberties with the true story, exaggerating the bear's actions and the reactions of those around it. The film's writers and directors have stated that they took inspiration from the absurdity of the situation and the darkly comedic tone of the story.

## Response to the film

The film has received a mixed response from critics, with some praising its darkly comedic tone and others criticizing its absurdity. The film's cast has received praise for their performances, with Keanu Reeves and J.K. Simmons receiving particular attention.

# Production

## Development and casting

The film was first announced in 2020, with Phil Lord and Christopher Miller set to write and direct. The film's cast was announced in 2021, with Keanu Reeves and J.K. Simmons joining the project.

## Filming

Filming took place in 2022 in the Pacific Northwest. The film's production team used a combination of practical and CGI effects to bring the bear to life.

# Music

The film's score was composed by Daniel Pemberton, who is known for his work on films such as "The Man from U.N.C.L.E." and "Steve Jobs." The film's soundtrack features a mix of electronic and orchestral elements, reflecting the film's darkly comedic tone.

# Release

## Theatrical

The film was released in theaters on February 24, 2023. The film received a wide release, with screenings in over 3,000 theaters.

## Home media

The film was released on digital platforms on March 15, 2023, and on Blu-ray and DVD on April 1, 2023.

# Reception

## Box office

The film was a commercial success, grossing over $150 million worldwide. The film's box office performance was boosted by its wide release and positive word-of-mouth.

## Critical response

The film received a mixed response from critics, with some praising its darkly comedic tone and others criticizing its absurdity. On Rotten Tomatoes, the film has a 52% approval rating, with an average rating of 5.5/10. On Metacritic, the film has a score of 54 out of 100, based on 25 reviews.

## Accolades

The film received several award nominations, including a nomination for Best Supporting Actor for J.K. Simmons at the 2023 National Board of Review Awards.

# Legacy

Cocaine Bear has had a lasting impact on popular culture, with references to the film appearing in various forms of media. The film's darkly comedic tone and absurdity have made it a cult classic, and it continues to be celebrated by fans of the genre.

**Acquisition of Twitter by Elon Musk**

The acquisition of Twitter by Elon Musk refers to the complex and multifaceted process of Musk's takeover bid, attempted termination, and eventual completion of the purchase of the social media platform. The acquisition was a highly publicized and closely watched event, with far-reaching implications for social media, technology, and global business.

**Introduction**

In the spring of 2022, Elon Musk, the CEO of SpaceX and Tesla, Inc., announced that he had acquired a significant stake in Twitter, Inc., the parent company of the social media platform Twitter. This move marked the beginning of a tumultuous and unprecedented takeover bid, which would ultimately result in Musk's acquisition of the company. The acquisition was met with both enthusiasm and skepticism, with many questioning Musk's intentions and the potential consequences of his ownership.

**#Prelude**

### **Background**

Twitter, Inc. was founded in 2006 by Jack Dorsey, Evan Williams, Biz Stone, and Noah Glass. The company went public in 2013 and has since become one of the largest and most influential social media platforms in the world. Twitter has been at the center of numerous controversies and debates, including issues related to free speech, online harassment, and misinformation.

### **Early developments**

In the years leading up to Musk's takeover bid, Twitter had faced increasing pressure to improve its moderation policies and address concerns around hate speech and misinformation. The company had also faced financial struggles, with declining user growth and revenue. These challenges created an environment in which a potential acquisition or takeover bid was seen as a viable option for the company.

**#Buyout offer**

### **Takeover bid**

On April 4, 2022, Elon Musk announced that he had acquired a 9.2% stake in Twitter, Inc., making him the company's largest shareholder. This move prompted speculation about Musk's intentions and potential plans for the company. Musk's takeover bid was seen as a surprise move, as he had previously been a vocal critic of Twitter's moderation policies and had expressed concerns about the platform's impact on society.

### **Acquisition announcement**

On April 14, 2022, Musk announced that he would be taking Twitter private in a $44 billion deal. The acquisition was seen as a major development in the world of social media and technology, with many analysts and investors speculating about the potential implications for the company and its users.

**#Attempted termination**

### **Alleged hold**

On July 8, 2022, Musk announced that he was terminating his acquisition bid, citing concerns about the number of fake accounts on the platform. Twitter's board of directors responded by filing a lawsuit against Musk, alleging that he had breached his contractual obligations and was attempting to walk away from the deal.

### **Attempted withdrawal by Musk**

Musk's decision to terminate the acquisition bid was seen as a surprise move, as many had expected the deal to go through. The attempted withdrawal sparked a series of high-stakes negotiations between Musk and Twitter's board of directors, with both sides vying for control of the company.

**#Revival and closing**

### **Revitalization of bid**

On October 4, 2022, Musk announced that he would be reviving his acquisition bid, citing a new agreement with Twitter's board of directors. The revised deal included a number of concessions, including a lower purchase price and a reduced number of employees.

### **Completion of purchase**

On October 27, 2022, Musk completed the purchase of Twitter, Inc. in a $44 billion deal. The acquisition marked a major milestone in the history of the company, with many speculating about the potential implications for the platform and its users.

### **Post-acquisition**

These included the introduction of a new moderation policy, the reinstatement of banned accounts, and the launch of a number of new features. The acquisition also sparked a number of high-profile debates and controversies, including issues related to free speech, online harassment, and misinformation.

**Boris Johnson**

Boris Johnson is a British politician who served as the Prime Minister of the United Kingdom from 2019 to 2022. He was a prominent figure in British politics for over three decades, holding various positions in government and Opposition.

**Early life and education**

### **Childhood**

Boris Johnson was born on June 19, 1964, in New York City to Stanley Johnson and Charlotte Johnson Wahl, a writer and artist, respectively. His father was a British diplomat, and his family moved to the United Kingdom when Johnson was a child. He was educated at Ashdown House in East Sussex and later at Eton College.

### **Eton and Oxford: 1977–1987**

Johnson attended Eton College from 1977 to 1983, where he was a member of the school's debating team and the editor of the school newspaper, _The Eton Chronicle_. He then went on to study Classics at Balliol College, Oxford, graduating with a third-class degree in 1987.

**Early career**

### **The Times and The Daily Telegraph: 1987–1994**

After graduating from Oxford, Johnson began his career in journalism, working as a reporter for _The Times_ from 1987 to 1988 and later as a leader writer for _The Daily Telegraph_ from 1988 to 1994. During this time, he became known for his humorous and satirical writing style.

### **Political columnist: 1994–1999**

Johnson joined _The Telegraph_ as a political columnist in 1994, where he became a prominent voice on the Conservative Party. He was a strong supporter of then-Prime Minister John Major and wrote numerous articles defending his government.

### **The Spectator and MP for Henley: 1999–2008**

In 1999, Johnson became the editor of _The Spectator_, a position he held until 2005. He also became the Member of Parliament for Henley from 2001 to 2008, serving as a junior shadow minister for the arts and a member of the House of Commons Culture, Media and Sport Committee.

#### **Becoming an MP**

Johnson won the seat of Henley in the 2001 general election, defeating the Liberal Democrat candidate by a margin of 4,000 votes. He was elected at the age of 37, becoming one of the youngest Conservative MPs at the time.

#### **Second term**

In the 2005 general election, Johnson was re-elected as the MP for Henley, increasing his majority to 11,000 votes. During this time, he continued to serve as a junior shadow minister and a member of the Culture, Media and Sport Committee.

**Mayor of London (2008–2016)**

### **Mayoral election: 2007–2008**

Johnson announced his candidacy for the Mayor of London in 2007, running against Labour's Ken Livingstone. The election was held on May 1, 2008, and Johnson won with 53% of the vote.

### **First term: 2008–2012**

Johnson's first term as Mayor of London saw the introduction of the Congestion Charge, increased funding for transport infrastructure, and the creation of the London Living Wage. He also oversaw the development of the Olympic Park for the 2012 Summer Olympics.

#### **Policies**

Johnson's policies as Mayor focused on improving transport, promoting economic growth, and enhancing the quality of life for Londoners. He implemented various initiatives, including the creation of the London Rapid Transit system and the expansion of the London Underground.

#### **Relations with the police, finance, and the media**

Johnson's relationship with the police was marked by controversy, particularly over the handling of the 2011 England riots. He also faced criticism from the media and financial institutions over his handling of the London economy and his policies on business regulation.

#### **Re-election campaign**

Johnson was re-elected as Mayor in 2012, defeating Labour's Ken Livingstone with 51% of the vote. His second term saw the introduction of the London Bus Franchising scheme and the development of the Garden Bridge project.

**Second term: 2012–2016**

Johnson's second term as Mayor saw the implementation of various policies, including the creation of the London Business Board and the expansion of the London Underground. He also oversaw the development of the Crossrail project and the introduction of the Ultra Low Emission Zone.

**Return to Parliament**

### **Brexit campaign: 2015–2016**

Johnson played a key role in the 2016 EU referendum campaign, advocating for the UK to leave the European Union. He was a prominent figure in the Leave campaign, writing numerous articles and appearing in various media outlets to promote the case for Brexit.

### **Foreign Secretary: 2016–2018**

After the Brexit vote, Johnson was appointed Foreign Secretary by Prime Minister Theresa May. He served in this position until July 2018, when he resigned in protest over the Chequers agreement.

### **Return to the backbenches: 2018–2019**

After resigning as Foreign Secretary, Johnson returned to the backbenches, where he continued to advocate for Brexit and criticize the Conservative government's handling of the issue.

#### **Journalism**

Johnson returned to journalism, writing articles for _The Telegraph_ and other publications. He also appeared in various media outlets, including television and radio, to promote his views on Brexit and other issues.

#### **2019 Conservative Party leadership election**

Johnson announced his candidacy for the Conservative Party leadership in June 2019, running against other prominent Conservative MPs. He won the leadership election with 66% of the vote, becoming the new Prime Minister of the United Kingdom.

**Premiership (2019–2022)**

### **First term (July–December 2019)**

Johnson's first term as Prime Minister saw the implementation of various policies, including the withdrawal from the European Union and the introduction of the Brexit deal. He also oversaw the creation of a new cabinet and the introduction of various austerity measures.

#### **Brexit policy**

Johnson's Brexit policy focused on implementing the withdrawal agreement and negotiating new trade deals with the European Union and other countries. He also introduced various measures to mitigate the impact of Brexit on the economy and society.

#### **First Cabinet**

Johnson's first cabinet was announced in July 2019, featuring a mix of experienced politicians and new faces. The cabinet included prominent figures such as Chancellor Sajid Javid and Home Secretary Priti Patel.

#### **Loss of working majority**

In September 2019, Johnson's Conservative Party lost its working majority in the House of Commons, following the defection of several MPs to the Liberal Democrats. This made it difficult for Johnson to pass legislation, particularly on Brexit.

#### **2019 general election**

Johnson called a general election in October 2019, which was held on December 12, 2019. The Conservative Party won a majority of 80 seats, giving Johnson a clear mandate to implement his policies.

**Second term (December 2019 – September 2022)**

Johnson's second term as Prime Minister saw the implementation of various policies, including the introduction of the National Living Wage and the expansion of the National Health Service. He also oversaw the development of the UK's response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

#### **Second Cabinet**

Johnson's second cabinet was announced in December 2019, featuring a mix of experienced politicians and new faces. The cabinet included prominent figures such as Chancellor Rishi Sunak and Home Secretary Priti Patel.

#### **COVID-19 pandemic**

Johnson's government played a key role in responding to the COVID-19 pandemic, introducing various measures to slow the spread of the virus and support affected businesses and individuals. The government's response was widely criticized, particularly over the initial delay in implementing lockdown measures.

#### **Immigration**

Johnson's government introduced various measures to reform the UK's immigration system, including the creation of a points-based system and the introduction of a new visa regime.

#### **Legislative agenda**

Johnson's legislative agenda focused on implementing various policies, including the introduction of a new Brexit deal and the expansion of the National Health Service.

#### **2021 Downing Street refurbishment controversy**

In 2021, Johnson's government faced criticism over the refurbishment of the Downing Street flat, with allegations that the costs had been misrepresented. The controversy led to an investigation by the Parliamentary Standards Commissioner.

#### **Owen Paterson controversy**

In 2021, Johnson's government faced criticism over the proposed reform of the parliamentary standards system, which would have allowed for the reappointment of MP Owen Paterson. The controversy led to widespread criticism and the eventual defeat of the government's plan.

#### **Partygate scandal**

In 2022, Johnson's government faced criticism over the Partygate scandal, which involved allegations of parties being held in Downing Street during the COVID-19 pandemic. The scandal led to widespread criticism and the eventual resignation of Johnson.

#### **Starmer slur controversy**

In 2022, Johnson faced criticism over a slur made against Keir Starmer, which was widely condemned as misogynistic and sexist.

#### **Vote of confidence**

In June 2022, Johnson faced a vote of confidence from his own MPs, which he won with 64% of the vote.

#### **June 2022 by-elections**

In June 2022, the Conservative Party suffered a series of by-election defeats, which further eroded Johnson's majority.

#### **Pincher scandal**

In July 2022, Johnson's government faced criticism over the Pincher scandal, which involved allegations of misconduct by MP Chris Pincher.

#### **Mass resignations**

In July 2022, Johnson's government faced a mass resignation of ministers, which further eroded his authority.

#### **Announcement of resignation**

On July 7, 2022, Johnson announced his resignation as Prime Minister, citing a loss of confidence in his ability to lead the Conservative Party.

**Environmental policies**

Johnson's government introduced various environmental policies, including the creation of a new green bank and the introduction of a carbon pricing mechanism.

**Foreign policy**

Johnson's government played a key role in shaping the UK's foreign policy, particularly with regards to Brexit and the European Union. He also oversaw the development of the UK's response to various international crises, including the conflict in Ukraine and the COVID-19 pandemic.

#### **Hong Kong and China**

Johnson's government played a key role in responding to the crisis in Hong Kong, including the introduction of new visa regimes and the condemnation of Chinese actions.

#### **Afghanistan**

Johnson's government played a key role in responding to the conflict in Afghanistan, including the evacuation of British citizens and the condemnation of Taliban actions.

#### **UK–EU trade negotiation**

Johnson's government played a key role in negotiating new trade deals with the European Union, including the introduction of a new Brexit deal.

#### **Russia and Ukraine**

Johnson's government played a key role in responding to the conflict in Ukraine, including the introduction of new sanctions and the condemnation of Russian actions.

**Post-premiership (2022–present)**

Johnson has continued to play a prominent role in British politics, although his influence has been diminished since his resignation as Prime Minister. He has written articles for various publications and has continued to advocate for his views on various issues.

**Political positions and ideology**

Johnson's political positions and ideology are complex and multifaceted. He has been a strong advocate for Brexit and has played a key role in shaping the UK's response to the European Union. He has also been a strong supporter of the Conservative Party and has played a key role in shaping its policies.

#### **Environment**

Johnson's government introduced various environmental policies, including the creation of a new green bank and the introduction of a carbon pricing mechanism. He has also been a strong supporter of the transition to renewable energy and has played a key role in promoting the development of new green technologies.

#### **Immigration and the European Union**

Johnson's government introduced various measures to reform the UK's immigration system, including the creation of a points-based system and the introduction of a new visa regime. He has also been a strong advocate for the UK's withdrawal from the European Union and has played a key role in shaping the UK's response to the European Union.

#### **Unionism and devolution**

Johnson's government played a key role in promoting the unity of the United Kingdom, including the introduction of new measures to strengthen the union. He has also been a strong supporter of devolution, including the introduction of new powers for Scotland and Wales.

**Public image**

Johnson's public image is complex and multifaceted. He has been a popular figure in British politics, particularly among Conservative voters. However, he has also been criticized for his handling of various issues, including the COVID-19 pandemic and the Brexit negotiations.

**Personal life**

Johnson is married to Carrie Symonds, a former Conservative Party staffer. He has four children, including two from a previous marriage to Marina Wheeler.

#### **Religion**

Johnson is a Christian and has spoken about the importance of his faith in his life.

#### **Relationships**

Johnson has been known for his relationships with various women, including his former wife Marina Wheeler and his current wife Carrie Symonds.

#### **Family and ancestors**

Johnson comes from a prominent British family, including his father Stanley Johnson and his grandfather Norman Stanley Acland Johnson. He has also been known for his interests in history and genealogy.

**Honours**

Johnson has been awarded various honors, including the Order of the British Empire (OBE) and the Knight Bachelor (Kt).

**Works**

Johnson has written various books, including _Seventy-Two Virgins_ and _The Dream of Rome_. He has also written articles for various publications, including _The Telegraph_ and _The Spectator_.

**Notes**

This article is a comprehensive overview of Boris Johnson's life and career. However, it is not an exhaustive account of all of his actions and decisions.

**References**

This article relies on various sources, including news articles, books, and online resources.

Pelé

Edson Arantes do Nascimento, commonly known as Pelé, is a Brazilian former professional footballer who is widely regarded as one of the greatest players of all time. Born on October 23, 1940, in Três Corações, Brazil, Pelé rose to international prominence in the late 1950s and dominated the sport for over two decades. He is a three-time World Cup winner, a two-time Copa Libertadores winner, and a three-time Intercontinental Cup winner.

#Early years

Pelé was born to Dondinho, a professional footballer, and Celeste Arantes, a housewife. He grew up in a poor family in Três Corações, where his father played for the local football team. Pelé's early life was marked by poverty and hardship, but his father's passion for football inspired him to pursue a career in the sport. Pelé began playing football at the age of six and quickly showed exceptional talent. He joined the local football club, Bauru Athletic Club, and later moved to Santos Football Club, where he would spend most of his professional career.

#Club career

##Santos

###1956–1962: early years with Santos and declared a national treasure

Pelé joined Santos in 1956, at the age of 15, and quickly became a key player for the team. He made his professional debut in 1956 and scored his first goal in 1957. Santos won the Brazilian Championship in 1958, and Pelé's performance earned him national recognition. In 1958, he was declared a national treasure by the Brazilian government, and his image appeared on the front pages of newspapers and magazines across the country.

###1962–1965: Copa Libertadores success

Santos won the Copa Libertadores in 1962, and Pelé's performance in the tournament cemented his status as a global superstar. He scored 17 goals in the tournament, including a hat-trick in the final against Boca Juniors. Santos repeated their success in 1963, winning the Copa Libertadores again. Pelé's dominance on the field and his charisma off the field made him a beloved figure in Brazil and around the world.

###1965–1974: O Milésimo and final years with Santos

In 1965, Santos won the Intercontinental Cup, defeating Internazionale 1-0 in the final. Pelé scored his 1000th goal in 1969, in a match against Vasco da Gama. He played for Santos until 1974, winning numerous titles and individual awards. Pelé's time with Santos was marked by incredible success and personal growth, both on and off the field.

##Tours with Santos

In 1967, Santos embarked on a tour of Europe, playing matches in England, Scotland, and Spain. The tour was a huge success, with Santos winning all but one of their matches. Pelé's performance on the tour cemented his status as a global superstar, and he became a household name in Europe.

##New York Cosmos

In 1975, Pelé joined the New York Cosmos, a team in the North American Soccer League. He played for the Cosmos until 1977, winning the NASL championship in 1977. Pelé's time with the Cosmos was marked by incredible success, both on and off the field. He became a beloved figure in New York City and around the world, and his performances on the field were met with critical acclaim.

#International career

##1958 World Cup

##1959 South American Championship

##1962 World Cup

##1970 World Cup

Pelé played in his final World Cup in 1970, where Brazil won the tournament. He scored four goals in the tournament, including two in the final against Italy.

#Style of play

Pelé was a versatile player who could play in various positions on the field. He was a skilled dribbler, a prolific goal-scorer, and an exceptional passer. He was known for his lightning-fast speed, his exceptional ball control, and his ability to score goals from anywhere on the field. Pelé's playing style was characterized by his creativity, his vision, and his ability to read the game.

#Legacy

Pelé's legacy is unparalleled in the world of football. He is widely regarded as one of the greatest players of all time, and his impact on the sport has been felt for generations. He is a three-time World Cup winner, a two-time Copa Libertadores winner, and a three-time Intercontinental Cup winner. Pelé was inducted into the FIFA 100, a list of the greatest living footballers, in 2004. He was also inducted into the Brazilian Football Hall of Fame in 1995.

Pelé is a Catholic, and he has spoken publicly about the importance of his faith in his life. He has also been involved in various charitable initiatives and has worked with the Catholic Church to promote social justice and human rights.

##Health

Pelé has been open about his health struggles throughout his career. He has undergone numerous surgeries and has struggled with various health issues, including a bout of tuberculosis in 1966. Despite his health struggles, Pelé has remained active and has continued to promote football development and education in Brazil.

#After football

After retiring from football in 1977, Pelé remained involved in the sport. He became a coach, a commentator, and a promoter of football development and education in Brazil. He has also been involved in various business ventures and has worked with various organizations to promote social justice and human rights.

#Death and funeral

Pelé passed away on December 29, 2022, at the age of 82, due to complications from colon cancer. His funeral was held on January 1, 2023, in Santos, Brazil, and was attended by thousands of mourners. His body was laid to rest in the Vila Belmiro cemetery, next to the Santos Football Club stadium.
